title: Cleanups on docker test images
body:
* makes all test images have a classpath of 'classes:lib/*'
  * This allows more simple changes to images, like patching classes
  * This is used for testing things like Cassandra tracing plugin
* adds `LOGGING_LEVEL` arg to cassandra and kafka
  * This makes it a lot easier to figure out problems customizing images
  * This also switches from stderr to stdout as it looks bad otherwise
* Updates ITs to use more recent images
* Has cassandra use Java 11 opens regardless of v3 or v4

title: Adjusts Cassandra image to work with JRE 11 and preps for Cassandra 4
body:
This adds some workarounds for Cassandra when used on JRE 11, allowing
us a single base image in this repo (note zipkin-dependencies still
uses JRE 8 until Elasticsearch updates their spark support).

A single base image helps us as we don't need to download a couple
hundred meg only for one storage option. This also carves in Cassandra
4 support based on 4.0.0-beta-3 which passes almost all tests, but
deserves to wait until the next beta before we formalize in any way.

title: Moves to GitHub actions build
body:
On CI:
  * Travis is still cutoff despite over a week of email.
  * We have to switch to GitHub actions to avoid paralyzing the project

On docker images:
  * zipkin-mysql and zipkin-ui now FROM openzipkin/alpine image, to ensure architectures like amd64 are uniform.
  * test images are reorganized under [docker/test-images] to help understand what's production or not.
  * [build-bin/docker_push] pushes test-images, but only to ghcr.io

On [build-bin]
  * [build-bin] largely reuses scripts used in other projects like zipkin-storage-kafka
  * This is discussed in [build-bin/README.md]


[zipkin-lens] is a node.js project, which has some additional concerns
* [build-bin/maybe_install_npm] is used to build on an unsupported node.js architecture.
* [build-bin/maven_go_offline] additionally seeds the NPM cache

On test:
* [build-bin/test], used by [.github/workflows/test.yml] runs Maven unit and integration tests.
* [.github/workflows/readme_test.yml] tests build commands in [zipkin-server] and [docker]
* zipkin, zipkin-lens and zipkin-slim Docker builds use `RELEASE_FROM_MAVEN_BUILD=true`
  * this avoids invoking Maven builds from within Docker, which are costly and fragile

On deploy:
* [build-bin/javadoc_to_gh_pages] pushes Javadoc to the gh-pages branch on N.M.L branch, but not master.

title: WIP: Support docker build for s390x
body:
As part of the work to support the [Knative](https://github.com/knative) pipeline for the s390x architecture, the dependency of the docker image `openzipkin/zipkin` was identified (https://github.com/knative/eventing/blob/master/test/config/monitoring.yaml#L46).

This PR is to resolve the dependency. 

The review can be started after the PR in `docker-java` (https://github.com/openzipkin/docker-java/pull/46) is merged. It will be on hold until then.

title: Matches versions on Docker quick check and uses default Docker package
body:
This uses the same Ubuntu and JDK version we use in the release process
for Docker "quick checks" which only build and verify containers start.

This style of check doesn't imply running integration tests, and can
identify issues far quicker as a result. Using the same OS dist and JDK
as Travis helps us share setup knowledge and reduce variables when
troubleshooting one vs another.

This also removes explicit version control of Docker, to prevent build outages
caused by rate limits. Instead, we use the implicit version of Docker, which
is new enough for our checks.

title: Fixes where benchmarks (40m jar) accidentally pushed to maven central
body:
This ensures benchmarks doesn't end up deployed to maven central, which
both clutters and delays our deployment. Before, it didn't actually skip
nexus-maven-plugin. Rather that attempt to disable 3 plugins, this makes
the benchmarks module itself optional, disabling on deployment.

This also increase the sync timeout as when I tried to re-sync a failed
attempt it.. timed out. It seems most overriding this set the value to
20m which makes sense as likely double the time needed.

title: Updates to latest dependencies and deletes invoker tests
body:
We originally supported server extensions, and so had Maven invoker
tests which isolate the classpath to hit a few areas. This deletes those
tests as we now use Docker for integrated server tests. This speeds up
the non-docker build quite a bit.

This also prunes the dependencies used in zipkin-server as the default
spring boot starter for test pulls in different versions of common
libraries such as assertj and jupiter. The only cost is maintaining the
spring-test version, which is only used in a few test runners, so not
particularly fragile.

repo.name: zipkin

title: Removes root dependency management
body:
Before, we imported BOMs at the root-most scope. This implies any
consumer of any library imports the same BOM. For example, I noticed
after clean installing brave-opentracing, that it was importing Netty's
BOM.

Root-level dependency management tempts us to accidentally add
dependencies to Zipkin's most core library. The convenience is not worth
the risk. Hence, this pushes out dependency management nearer to where
they are used.

title: Stops using zipkin-builder Docker image
body:
This stops building a zipkin-builder image. This means that you can't
build Zipkin from source using only Docker.

Ex. a variant of the following won't work for source, only releases from
Maven central:
```bash
$ docker build https://github.com/openzipkin/zipkin
```

This implies Docker Hub auto-builds won't work for source releases,
which is not an issue as we don't use it anymore, and also Docker Hub
quota is problematic.

The pressure to remove source builds became strong when we started to
support multi-architecture builds. It is extremely time consuming to
attempt to run Maven and NPM inside of Docker, with an arm64 emulator.
This displaces effort that is sorely needed elsewhere and generally makes
the build unapproachable.

Since the Zipkin server itself is platform independent Java and client-
ide Javascript, there's no architectural impact to re-using the same
binaries for N arch builds. For example, this reworks the GitHub Action
validator to only build Zipkin once and use it for all the containers
to check.

Fixes #3271

containing zipkin and zipkin-slim jars. This introduces `RELEASE_FROM_CONTEXT`

title: Deprecates Cassandra v1 schema for removal in Zipkin 2.23
body:
The "cassandra3" storage type relies on Cassandra v3.11.3+. This has
been out for over 2 years. We will soon need to support v4 which is
coming out of beta soon. Maintenance on the v1 schema has been immense
and I don't think volunteers would do any more refactors of it. It is
time to deprecate and remove the v1 schema.

"cassandra3" uses UDTs and optimized SASI indexing.  While SASI is
marked experimental, it is enabled by default in recent Cassandra
versions. Some clones of Cassandra may choose to not support SASI, but
this does not mean we must maintain an ancient schema. Those who must
use a clone can disable search, which avoids SASI.

It is likely that when Cassandra 4 comes out, we will use SAI indexing
instead with some migration instructions. However, SASI as used today
has been used in production for 2 years. Even if the feature is marked
experimental, it is well practiced here.

title: Removes Cassandra querybuilder dependency

This removes the querybuilder dependency in efforts to reduce size.

While this saves a couple hundred K, it doesn't change things further as
datastax core lib depends still on a 2.8M shaded guava jar.

I've raised a help request on that for now, but reducing the API surface
area to only core libs should help anyway.

https://groups.google.com/u/1/a/lists.datastax.com/g/java-driver-user/c/aN7NkxX_yQk

title: Refactors integration tests to be more isolated
body:
This makes all integration tests use unique data. Notably, they no
longer use constant trace ID or service names, as this can lead to
difficulty when a keyspace is re-used. For example, service names and
trace IDs are often partitions. When debugging it is easier when test
data is isolated by a service name as it can be easily queried.

This also pulls the heaviest tests into their own classes so that they
don't overload the storage containers used by the bulk of our tests.

Finally, this fixes a few glitches in the v1 cassandra storage.

title: Migrates to Datastax Driver v4
body:
This migrates to the Netty-based Datastax Driver v4, which no longer
uses guava. This is very different library architecture, most obvious in
how configuration is managed. This migration tries to be as conventional
as possible while retaining defaults as close to as they were as
possible.

Special thanks to @adutra and @olim7t who helped with translation things on the https://groups.google.com/a/lists.datastax.com/g/java-driver-user list

cc @openzipkin/cassandra 

Fixes  #2405
Fixes #1276

title: Tracing kafka collector
body:
Fix  #2872

Changes to enable self-tracing on kafka-collector. As mentioned on the issue, `RequestContextCurrentTraceContext` causes an issue to propagate traces.

From [Armeria Slack](https://line-armeria.slack.com/archives/C1NGPBUH2/p1598884943010400):

> We usually recommend to create a fake ServiceRequestContext  in that case.
> <https://armeria.dev/docs/advanced-unit-testing#using-a-fake-context-to-emulate-an-incoming-request>
> So we can emulate the event from the  kafka consumer as a request from a client.

title: Refactors Cassandra queries so they are cheaper and easier to migrate
body:
Before, we used labels a lot, and generally a lot of query builder code.
This switches most to positional syntax, which is cheaper and easier to
migrate to cassandra driver 4.

This also reformats everything to make the migration feel like less
change.

Finally, this consolidates as much code as possible, notably repetitive
inserts and queries, again to reduce the heft needed to upgrade later.

title: Finishes Docker refactoring
body:
This does several things of importance around Docker:

* Makes default heap for 'mem' 128m, slim 32m and otherwise 64m
  * We now use `-XX:+ExitOnOutOfMemoryError` instead of letting the process live on OOM
  * Before, memory was unbounded
* Consolidates zipkin production images similar to zipkin-dependencies:
  * See https://github.com/openzipkin/zipkin-dependencies/pull/181
  * This means no duplicated Dockerfile
* Removes detection of legacy docker links and associated profiles
  * these were added for an old docker-compose setup
  * added a README example for the ancient
* Makes ENTRYPOINT and HEALTHCHECK like other images
* Changes example to suggest applying logging via `command` not `JAVA_OPTS`
* Switches docker-compose examples to use imports
* Adds docker-compose-example.xml
* Consolidates RATIONALE
* Switches to GitHub actions to test images

title: elasticsearch: use backpressure to resolve streaming request flakes
body:
The `HttpResponse` was sent before the request are fully sent.
So the request was aborted after getting the response. This changes
to send the response after the request is fully received.

Fixes #3197

title: Fix a bug in the unit of duration
body:
resolve: https://github.com/openzipkin/zipkin/issues/3233

`formatDuration` requires a microsecond-value as its argument, but `trace.duration` is millisecond-value.
So we need to multiply `trace.duration` by 1000.

title: Allow use of JDK 15+
body:
This allows builds to work with JDK 15+ even if that JDK cannot compile
Java 1.6 anymore. Specifically, this removes Retrolambda, which formerly
rewrote our main tree to 1.6 bytecode. We had to do this as Retrolambda
no longer works in JDK 15.

In order to publish a JRE compatible 1.6 jar to Maven Central, we use
JDK during the release process (Travis). To ensure normal usage and
Docker can use JDK 15, we change our GitHub actions to use JDK 15.

This also adds a RATIONALE.md which covers the major aspects around
source, largely duplicated from Brave (though not exactly the same as
context slightly differs here.)

title: Ports MySQL test image to our conventions
body:
Particularly, this image adds HEALTHCHECK and deletes 100MB of binaries not used at runtime, making it 170MB (compared to the official mariadb image which is 400MB)

Once released, this completes our storage images: we can add a health condition on any storage image or kafka:

Ex.
```
    depends_on:
      storage:
        condition: service_healthy
      kafka-zookeeper:
        condition: service_healthy
```

title: Migrates Elasticsearch demo images to OSS license
body:
This uses OSS license for Elasticsearch 6 and 7, reducing the size of
the images. Image size is further reduced in 7 by using a recent change
to our JRE that allows Thai segmentation support (module jdk.localedata)

This also reduces test execution time by only executing the 7.8+ schema
test vs the entire suite again.

Finally, this enables HEALTHCHECK on the images, so that we can later
automatically test them. Even though these are demo images, if they
break, it can causes time loss.
